creator: Telpuialion
title: Tailgate Detractor (Table-top)
materials_required: Mini breadboard with a power rail
9V battery OR Arduino compatible USB cable
description: This project is a table-top demonstration of a tailgating detractor. It uses an ultrasonic sensor to detect objects within a certain range and then actuates an arm and hand to 'warn' the tailgater. The design is customizable and can be adapted for use in a real vehicle.
steps: 3D print the arm and hand components using the provided STL files or custom designs.
Connect the HC-SR04 Ultrasonic Range Sensor to the Arduino Uno: VCC to 5V, Trig to pin 3, Echo to pin 2, and Gnd to GND.
Connect the arm servo to the Arduino Uno: Black/Brown wire to ground, Red wire to 5V, and White/Orange wire to pin 6.
Connect the hand servo to the Arduino Uno: Black/Brown wire to ground, Red wire to 5V, and White/Orange wire to pin 5.
Ensure the breadboard power rails are properly connected to the Arduino ( '+' rail to 5V and '-' rail to GND).
Upload the provided Arduino code (Projectupdate.ino.ino) to the Arduino Uno using the Arduino IDE.
Cut two holes in the box for the proximity sensor.
Cut a slot in the box for the arm to move freely.
Determine where the Arduino will be placed and cut a hole for the USB cable if using a cable for power.
Affix the Arduino and breadboard to the base of the box and then affix the arm servo to the base.
Attach all wires to the breadboard and place the proximity sensor into its slot.
Attach the arm to the arm servo and the hand to the hand servo, using screws, cable ties, electrical tape, or super glue.
Glue the arm servo, along with the arm assembly, to the base of the box, considering a wooden strip for height adjustment.
Screw the top of the box on to complete the assembly.
